values.description:
We ran into a crash while going through the svg tutorial (see [this comment](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/327/svg_improvements#comment-13781391)). The same problem will occur for users compiling from source and do not have libgts-dev installed.

To reproduce the crash - try extrude [this svg file](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/raw/default/extrude_svg/files/wheel.svg) in model editor.

- Click `Add` under Custom Shapes > Import the svg > Extrude it > Crash

This PR prevents the crash and the user should see an error message about gts library not found.

if you already have gts and want to test this PR without uninstalling, add `#undef HAVE_GTS` to [MeshManager.cc:34](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/dbcec9f9bd09d7732bd686d51e488740ae681a14/gazebo/common/MeshManager.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#MeshManager.cc-34) then recompile

related issue #1710

[jenkins gpu-none](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/77/) - ok
values.title: Prevent crash when svg polyline extrusion fails

values.description:
This pull request makes it possible to open a new world from the server side.

Since the client is not there yet, a way to test it would be:

1. Build the example publishers added in this PR

1. Start `gzserver` with a world of your choosing

1. Publish either a new world or open world message using the standalone publishers:
 
    *  `./pub_new_world`

    * `./pub_open_world <full path>`


1. Now open `gzclient` and check that the new world has been opened and there are no traces of the old world.



[ABI](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20ABI%20jobs/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-vivid-amd64/66/) not broken
values.title: A whole new world (server side)

values.description:
We will be doing a sprint soon to fix as many gazebo tests as possible. In preparation, we have made a dashboard summarizing the state of our jenkins builds of the default branch on all our supported platforms:

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/

It uses the following color codes:

* Red: build failure
* Yellow: build completed with some warnings, cppcheck errors, or test failures
* Blue: clean build

The dashboard also summarizes how many warnings, cppcheck errors, and test failures are present on a given build. While working to catalog these failures, I've identified fixes for quite a few of them, which I've included in this pull request.

## Trusty fixes

* trusty, release mode has 2 [compiler warnings related to unused variables](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci_BTRelease-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/warnings). This is caused by using a variable only in a `GZ_ASSERT`, which is a no-op in release mode. Fixed in 84a2658

* trusty debug mode has a persistent timeout of `INTEGRATION_joint_gearbox` (issue #1824). I increased the timeout in 96548ab

## OS X test fixes

* `UNIT_Rand_TEST` fails on OS X (and also on [wily](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-wily-amd64-gpu-none/lastCompletedBuild/testReport/%28root%29/RandTest/Rand/)) by expecting a specific random number after setting the seed. I'm not sure we can expect all random number generators to be implemented in the same way, so I modified the test in 473acbf to expect repeatability after setting the seed, but not exact values.

* There are some tests that always fail on OSX (see issues #1219 and #1846) that I have disabled in b4d728e

* I fixed some osx GUI tests in 442df5f and also added some extra console output, since the console output from QTest's is attenuated in jenkins (issue #1845)

Since the fixes are all in specific commits, please consider approving the individual commits as you review this PR.

I'll post jenkins results as they are available.

* [OSX UNIT_ImagesView_TEST passed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/72/testReport/%28root%29/ImagesView_TEST/), and it [fails on default](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/28/testReport/UNIT_ImagesView_TEST/xml/_empty_/)
* [OSX UNIT_LayersWidget_TEST fixed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/72/testReport/%28root%29/LayersWidget_TEST/)
* [OSX UNIT_Projection_TEST fixed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/72/testReport/%28root%29/Projection_TEST/)
* no regressions in [trusty nvidia build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/73/)
* no related failures in [trusty no-gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/82/)
* regression of `UNIT_ImagesView_TEST` in [homebrew build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/75/), see discussion in comment thread
values.title: Fixes for tests and warnings

values.description: Changed calculation of parent link force/torque. Force on child is calculated in world frame (was child frame before), where the parent force/torque can simply be the negative of the child force/torque (before, parent force/torque was set to the negative child force/torque, which was specified in child link frame and was added to the overall torque in parent link frame). Now all torques are calculated in world frame, summed up and transformed into child and parent frame in the end.
values.title: changed the calculation of force/torque on parent link for gazebo::physics::ODEJoint::GetForceTorque()

summary.raw: Changed calculation of parent link force/torque. Now all torques are calculated in world frame, summed up and transformed into child and parent frame in the end.

values.description:
Currently the
[gpu-intel jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-vivid-amd64-gpu-intel/)
thinks that it is able to find a valid X11 instance, since there appears to be an X server named `:0` running on the system.
There is a problem with this X server, though, that causes [all the GUI tests to fail](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-vivid-amd64-gpu-intel/29/testReport/).
This pull request updates the display checking logic to check if `xwininfo -root` can be run successfully before declaring that a display has been found.

I've tested with a [gazebo-any gpu-intel](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-vivid-amd64-gpu-intel/9/) job, which fails to detect the display with this branch, so it does not build or run the GUI tests. Ultimately, this is an X11 configuration problem, which we should fix, but this logic is helpful for reducing jenkins noise.

[Diff without whitespace](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2111/check-for-valid-display-using-xwininfo/diff?w=1)

* [trusty nvidia build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/76/) still runs the GUI tests
values.title: Check for valid display using xwininfo -root

summary.raw:
Currently the
[gpu-intel jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-vivid-amd64-gpu-intel/)
thinks that it is able to find a valid X11 instance, since there appears to be an X server named `:0` running on the system.
There is a problem with this X server, though, that causes [all the GUI tests to fail](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-vivid-amd64-gpu-intel/29/testReport/).
This pull request updates the display checking logic to check if `xwininfo -root` can be run successfully before declaring that a display has been found.

I've tested with a [gazebo-any gpu-intel](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-vivid-amd64-gpu-intel/9/) job, which fails to detect the display with this branch, so it does not build or run the GUI tests. Ultimately, this is an X11 configuration problem, which we should fix, but this logic is helpful for reducing jenkins noise.

[Diff without whitespace](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2111/check-for-valid-display-using-xwininfo/diff?w=1)

* [trusty nvidia build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/76/) still runs the GUI tests
summary.html:
Currently the gpu-intel jenkins build thinks that it is able to find a valid X11 instance, since there appears to be an X server named :0 running on the system. There is a problem with this X server, though, that causes all the GUI tests to fail. This pull request updates the display checking logic to check if xwininfo -root can be run successfully before declaring that a display has been found.

I've tested with a gazebo-any gpu-intel job, which fails to detect the display with this branch, so it does not build or run the GUI tests. Ultimately, this is an X11 configuration problem, which we should fix, but this logic is helpful for reducing jenkins noise.

Diff without whitespace

  • trusty nvidia build still runs the GUI tests

values.description:
There are several tests that are [always failing](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci_BTCoverage-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/27/testReport/) during our coverage build of the default branch.

* The largest set of tests is related to a simbody run-time error when compiled in coverage mode (gazebo issue #1849). I tracked this down to the use of the `-fno-elide-constructors` compiler flag and [reported upstream](https://github.com/simbody/simbody/issues/468). I propose disabling the tests for now in coverage mode, since it's unclear whether a fix would be backported.

* The `test_fixture` standalone example has a linking error during coverage builds (undefined reference to `__gcov_init`, `__gcov_merge_add`). I propose disabling that portion of the examples build test as well.
values.title: Fix coverage tests

values.description:
We have some GUI tests that fail on Ubuntu when there is no active screen attached. We disable these tests in jenkins, and they consistently fail in my overnight testing. The list is not completely accurate, though:

* The [ViewAngleWidget_TEST](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/lastCompletedBuild/testReport/%28root%29/ViewAngleWidget_TEST/EmptyWorld/history/) usually fails without a screen (not sure why it sometimes passes in jenkins since it always fails in overnight testing), so I've added it to the list. **Update** Ian fixed this test and I merged it into this branch!
* There are 6 other tests in the list that actually pass without a screen ([jenkins results](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/80/testReport/)), so I've removed them from the list.

It would be even better to figure out how to make the tests pass without a screen, but we'll save that for another day.

I also alphabetized some cmake lists.

values.description:
This pull request implements the introspection manager as described [in this design](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/29).

API description:

* `Register()` / `Unregister` / `Items()` functions : Methods to be used by the components that want to register items in the introspection manager (data providers). As the manager is a singleton, the data provider needs to be located in the same process as the manager is running.

* Services available via Ignition Transport used by the components that want to create filters for receiving updates on some of the registered items (data consumers).

```
#!c++

/introspection/<manager_id>/filter_new
/introspection/<manager_id>/filter_update
/introspection/<manager_id>/filter_remove
/introspection/<manager_id>list
```

I recommend to look into `IntrospectionManager.hh` for details about the expected format message when using the transport services.

There's a second part in pull request #2123 that implements an `IntrospectionClient` class. This class is designed to help data consumers, as it offers a function-based API and hides most of the transport and internal details.

This also comes out of swarm. We had the ability to create standalone single Rays, but no way to do the same with a MultiRay.

Along the way I found the Ray-Cylinder collision test in ODE is broken in the case where rays intersect the end caps. I copied an updated collision check from ODE 0.13, and it seems to work. A separate pull request will backport this to gazebo7 and gazebo6.


resolves issue #636

This pull request adds an `IntrospectionClient` class. Most of the data consumers should use this class as an easier way to create, update or remove filters.

It also provides one function to list the IDs of all the introspection managers running and the items registered in a specific manager.

I recommend to look into the `IntrospectionClient_TEST.cc` for details about how to use the class.

values.description:
This is a precursor to a pull request that will cause tests to be linked only with the required libraries. This can greatly speed up test compilation for low-level libraries. The first commit ( a304ef9 ) is most useful, as it ensures that math tests don't have an implicit dependency on gazebo common (through AutoLogFixture). Three other commits remove an un-needed dependency from other tests.

* a304ef9: Remove dependency of gazebo math tests on common: don't use AutoLogFixture

* 68c37a6: Use AutoLogFixture instead of ServerFixture for Battery and RenderingConversions tests

* 2f8cc88: Remove gazebo::common dependency from EXAMPLE_* test

* 38e0c9f: Redact InertialWorld test that didn't have any useful expectations, and then use AutoLogFixture instead of ServerFixture

The final change is a quick fix to enable valgrind for all types of tests, not just GUI tests (see pull request #2075 for more info).

* 4a26e39: Enable valgrind for all tests, not just GUI tests
values.title: Reduce test dependencies

values.description:
Currently many of our tests link against unnecessary libraries. For example, compiling the math tests requires compiling all of `libgazebo`, which turns a 1 minute task into a 15 minute task.

This pull request replaces the hacky `GZ_BUILD_TESTS_EXTRA_EXE_SRCS` cmake variable with a keyword `EXTRA_LIBS` to the gz_build_tests macro specify which libraries to use for linking the tests that use gtest (the GUI tests using `QTest` are not modified). To test with a fresh build folder:

~~~
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
cd gazebo/math
make -j8
~~~

This will be much faster with this branch. The speed-up is most dramatic for math, but there is speed-up for most other tests that are touched here. Also, some folders have a mix of tests that are true unit tests, and tests that use `gazebo_test_fixture`, and I split them up accordingly.

There are still some missing dependencies (for example any test worlds that use plugins, or tests that invoke command-line tools), but I would prefer to save this for later.

[jenkins no-gpu is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/986/)
values.title: Only link relevant libraries to tests

values.description:
This builds on top of pull request #2129.

This is the first draft of the palette. The palette contains 3 tabs:

### Topics tab

#### Top pane

List of all topics advertised the moment the dialog was opened.

#### Bottom pane

List plottable fields for a topic selected on the top pane. The fields are hierarchically arranged. Those which are plottable can be dragged and dropped.

### Sim tab

#### Top pane

Empty by design

#### Bottom pane

Hard coded values (sim/real time and iterations) which can be dragged to the plot.

### Search tab

#### Top pane

Contains search box and search results from the other tabs. Some results can be dragged directly from here, others can be expanded on the bottom pane.

#### Bottom pane

Displays fields from whatever was selected on the top pane.

![plotpalette.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/825853685-plotpalette.png)
values.title: Plot Palette: Topics, Sim and Search

values.description:
our Qt tests link against `gazebo_gui` which doesn't seem to contain Qt resources. So running gui tests like `MainWindow_TEST` prints out various Qt warnings.

Adding `resources_RCC` to  `gazebo gui` fixes the problem. Alternatively, we will need to find out how to add it to the  `gz_build_qt_tests(${qt_tests})` command

values.description:
The `UNIT_IntrospectionClient_TEST` test is [failing to run on OS X](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/111/testReport/(root)/UNIT_IntrospectionClient_TEST/test_ran/). It seg-faults during the `UpdateFilter` sub-test. I've captured a [backtrace](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/6cb3c7fd2d8ef89e8b31) that implicates the `IntrospectionClient::RemoveAllFilters` function.

`RemoveAllFilters` has a loop that iterates over the `std::map` called `filters` in the private data pointer and calls `RemoveFilter` that erases elements from the map. It seems that there is a memory access error when trying to increment the iterator in the outer loop after its content has already been erased. I've modified the loop to precompute the next element in the map before calling `RemoveFilter`, which fixes the test failure on my machine.
values.title: Plotting: fix UNIT_IntrospectionClient_TEST on osx

summary.raw:
The `UNIT_IntrospectionClient_TEST` test is [failing to run on OS X](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/111/testReport/(root)/UNIT_IntrospectionClient_TEST/test_ran/). It seg-faults during the `UpdateFilter` sub-test. I've captured a [backtrace](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/6cb3c7fd2d8ef89e8b31) that implicates the `IntrospectionClient::RemoveAllFilters` function.

`RemoveAllFilters` has a loop that iterates over the `std::map` called `filters` in the private data pointer and calls `RemoveFilter` that erases elements from the map. It seems that there is a memory access error when trying to increment the iterator in the outer loop after its content has already been erased. I've modified the loop to precompute the next element in the map before calling `RemoveFilter`, which fixes the test failure on my machine.
summary.html:
The UNIT_IntrospectionClient_TEST test is failing to run on OS X. It seg-faults during the UpdateFilter sub-test. I've captured a backtrace that implicates the IntrospectionClient::RemoveAllFilters function.

RemoveAllFilters has a loop that iterates over the std::map called filters in the private data pointer and calls RemoveFilter that erases elements from the map. It seems that there is a memory access error when trying to increment the iterator in the outer loop after its content has already been erased. I've modified the loop to precompute the next element in the map before calling RemoveFilter, which fixes the test failure on my machine.

values.description:
Integrated qwt to create plots. 

  - The axis labels are currently hardcoded. 

  - Y axis will auto-scale but disabled when user zooms/pans with the mouse. 

  - X-axis auto scrolls as new data come in. Window size is set to 10 simulation seconds.

Integrated introspection client in PlotManager to provide `sim_time`. Also added sample data for a few test variables in the palette. 

Things to try:

- add a variable to the y container to create a new plot

- add a variable to another variable (which creates a multi-variable) to see one plot with multiple "plot curves"

- delete a variable to remove the corresponding plot curve

- reset simulation to see new plot curves added to the existing plot

TODOs

- Make plot title and variable labels editable

- Improve user interaction with plot (zoom, pan, etc)
values.title: Plot Window: part 3 - Canvas, plot, curve

values.description:
New `Uri` class used for naming entities and its properties.

The part5 pull request uses it for registering some of the model and world properties in the world.

A `Uri` is composed by three parts: 

* World: World name where the entity is contained. (e.g.:`default`)
* Entity: Hierarchy of entities. (e.g.: `model/model_1/link/link_1`)
* Parameter: Property of the entity (e.g.: `pose`).

A `Uri` has a `CanonicalUri()` function that returns a URI in string format. E.g.: `/world/default/model/model_1?p=pose`.
values.title: Plotting backend - part4 (naming)

* Adds a new `URI()` member function to the `Base` class. This is similar to `GetScopedName()` but we return a `URI`.

* Register the pose and linear velocity of all the models.

* Register the simulation time in the world.

* Simplified registration with a more convenient way of passing callbacks.

~~Note: this PR is built atop pull request #2144, which should be merged first.[ Here](#!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/introspection_part5%0Dintrospection_part4#diff)'s a better diff.~~

Another swarm pull request. It's common that a log file will not include a close `</gazebo_log>` tag. This is often because of a crash, or forced kill. 

This pull request adds the tag back into a log file when it is played.

[Jenkins from a different branch built against default](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/130/)

values.description:
Redo of pull request #2139.

Based on [this](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2139/plotting-backend-part4-naming/diff) Nate's branch and added some tweaks, validation and parsing from a string.

As we discussed in pull request #2139, this is a more generic approach for URIs.

A URI has now a scheme, path and query string. In Gazebo, we'll codify the entity inside the path and the property inside the query string.

I created a basic string tokenizer class for avoid using boost, or `<regex>` (not fully supported in all the compilers).
values.title: Plotting backend - part4 (naming)

summary.html:
Redo of pull request #2139.

Based on this Nate's branch and added some tweaks, validation and parsing from a string.

As we discussed in pull request #2139, this is a more generic approach for URIs.

A URI has now a scheme, path and query string. In Gazebo, we'll codify the entity inside the path and the property inside the query string.

I created a basic string tokenizer class for avoid using boost, or <regex> (not fully supported in all the compilers).

values.description:
Ran into a bug in the version of tinyxml2 that is released in ubuntu. Large log files, specifically large blocks of CDATA cause tinyxml2 to fail.

Fortunately version 3 of tinyxml2 works. 

This pull request changes gazebo to rely solely on the internal version of tinyxml2. I also removed public facing inclusion of tinyxml2 in LogPlay.

@\_jrivero\_ , do you think this will negatively affect anything?

I can't write a test for this because the test requires a very large log file, and we shouldn't include such a file in the gazebo sources. I have a 14GB log file on my PC that anyone can have for testing. 

[Jenkins](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2146)
values.title: Internal tinyxml2

values.description:
issue #1844 - during joint creation, setting the relative pose of child links after alignment causes the pose to be reset.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Go into model editor 

2. Add two links

3. Click on the joint icon to launch Joint Creation dialog

4. Select parent and child link

5. Go to `Align links` section in Joint Creation dialog and click on any align configuration button (e.g. X Align Max) and check the `Reverse` checkbox

6. Go to `Relative Pose` section and try set a new pose (e.g. set Z to 0.1) - this causes the child link to reset its pose


Expanded unit test. It doesn't make the original code fail though but still nice to have.

jenkins:

[gpu-nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/131/) - ok

[abi-checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-vivid-amd64/134/) - ok

summary.html:
issue #1844 - during joint creation, setting the relative pose of child links after alignment causes the pose to be reset.

Steps to reproduce:

  1. Go into model editor

  2. Add two links

  3. Click on the joint icon to launch Joint Creation dialog

  4. Select parent and child link

  5. Go to Align links section in Joint Creation dialog and click on any align configuration button (e.g. X Align Max) and check the Reverse checkbox

  6. Go to Relative Pose section and try set a new pose (e.g. set Z to 0.1) - this causes the child link to reset its pose

Expanded unit test. It doesn't make the original code fail though but still nice to have.
